It is not normal for Deputy Barnes to do that and I know that now the Chair's attention has been drawn to it she will not persist and will allow Deputy McCartan to proceed without interruption.
Certainly.

To make a major distinction between rape by natural intercourse and other horrific forms of assault seems to undermine this understanding. Second, it seems that the offence of aggravated sexual assault will be viewed as less serious than rape, and for that reason we are not happy with the approach taken in the Bill. In the final report prepared by the Law Reform Commission they discussed at length the majority recommendation to broaden the definition of rape. Paragraph 14 states:

We accordingly recommend that the crime of rape should be defined by Statute so as to include non-consensual sexual penetration of the vagina, anus and mouth of a person by the penis of another person, or of the vagina and anus of a person by an inaminate object held or manipulated by another person.

In this form the crime could be committed against men and women. The Workers' Party fully support that view in terms of a definition and I would urge the Minister, in looking at the Bill before Committee Stage, to again consider amending it to meet with the majority view of the Law Reform Commission. There is dissent in regard to that recommendation by two members of the commission and that is outlined on page 22 of the report. Their view is primarily that “Changes in the definition of the crime will not result in the more efficient realisation of the criminal law's primary objective, namely, the apprehension, conviction and punishment of the guilty”. They tend to the conservative view that is reflected in the gradation approach of the Minister in the Bill.

MainHeading.P: Criminal law must have a wider, more positive and active role to play than merely the primary objective as set out by the two people who comprised the minority dissent. There must be more to our legislation than merely the apprehension, conviction and punishment of the guilty. As legislators, we should use our legislation to attempt to lay down social parameters and directives from this House. It is important in this context, particularly as we are addressing a definition of rape for the second time in this decade, that we get it right on this occasion. The basic argument of those who seek the broader definition is that we should mark our disapproval of all forms of aggravated sexual assaults on women and men by a broad definition and use of the word “rape”, recognising that that has, in its connotation, serious and emotive regard the community.

There is no doubt that the crime of rape, to be called a rapist, to be made answerable in a court to a charge of rape and, most of all, to be found guilty and sentenced for it is a very serious and emotive event to occur, and so it should be. We argue it should not simply be confined to the very limited sense as contained in the Minister's current definition. We think that all of those other inanimate penetrations referred to in the definition by the Law Reform Commission's majority report are as heinous and as violent on the woman or man as the classical current definition.

There is an interesting debate and argument outlined in the consultative paper and also in the deliberation on the concept that perhaps conception could result from the act of “pure rape”. I do not think that can be a factor in defining what can amount to the act of rape as we should define it in this House. It is an act of serious, aggravated assault, of violence towards the person in the first instance and that is the approach we should take in seeking to achieve a definition.

As I have said, this is a matter that we will obviously have to address on Committee Stage. I hope the Minister will have regard for the views of all Deputies on this side of the House, for the majority view of the Law Reform Commission and indeed the views not just of women but of all the organisations referred to in the reports right across the spectrum who are concerned about this problem.

We recognise obviously that there are drafting difficulties, that it is a problem that will have to be very carefully looked at but I do not believe it is beyond the capacity of the Minister and his officials to come up with a formula that would receive the support of this House. There exists in a number of other jurisdictions such broadly based legislative proposals that could well be borrowed and used as the yardstick to work with. Certainly The Workers' Party will seek to assist the Minister in every regard should he pursue this line of approach.
Debate adjourned.

MainHeading.LHead: Estimates for Public Services 1990 and Public
MainHeading.Title: Estimates for Public Services 1990 and Public Capital Programme 1990: Motion (Resumed).
MainHeading.P: The following motion was moved by the Minister for Finance on 30 November 1989:
That Dáil Éireann takes note of the 1990 Estimates for the Public Services (Abridged Version) and of the 1990 Summary Public Capital Programme.
Debate resumed on amendment No. 1:
To add the following:

“That Dáil Éireann considers that the 1990 Estimates will do nothing to reverse the trend of inequality and disadvantage that has been the consequence of Government policy since 1987. Dáil Éireann considers that improved economic growth must be equitably distributed, must lead to the creation of jobs through the creation and retention of wealth in Ireland, and must be accompanied by social improvements in the areas of health, education, housing and social welfare here at home, and by an improved contribution to the alleviation of famine and poverty in the world around us. Against the background of an improved outlook for the economy, Dáil Éireann considers that the failure of the Government to make additional resources available in the following areas is particularly deplorable, and condemns the Government in respect of:
—Its failure to provide any specific programme to combat the continuing scandal of emigration;

—Its decision to reduce the Capital Allocation for the provision of health facilities by 8.5 per cent in real terms, notwithstanding the increasing and urgent demand for additional hospital wards and beds and notes that such a cut will
inevitably delay, for instance, work on the Tallaght Regional Hospital;

—Its failure to provide sufficient current resources in the health allocation to allow for the reopening and adequate staffing of hospital beds and wards, notwithstanding the fact that the use of accident and emergency services as the only means of access to hospital beds for a great many people is leading to a resurgence of long waiting lists for elective treatment in public hospitals;

—Its failure to make any additional allocation available for the development of additional residential, training and employment opportunities for people with a mental handicap, even though it is now reliably estimated that in the Eastern Health Board area alone, for instance, a total of 328 residential places are needed immediately, with a further 567 places needed in the years after 1990;

—Its decision to maintain capital spending on the provision of educational facilities at the same deplorably low level as last year, which was the worst year for capital investment in education in the 1980s;

—Its decision to cut Exchequer current spending on First Level Education by 1 per cent in real terms, and to freeze expenditure on Second Level Education, having regard to the growing level of inequality within our education system, and its decision to use European funding to replace Exchequer expenditure at all levels of our education system;
—Its continuing covert approach to restricting access to Social Welfare programmes, and its lack of adequate funding for programmes
whose main aim is to combat poverty;

—Its deplorable decision effectively to force local authorities to finance their housing programmes out of the sale of local authority houses, thereby ensuring that the housing crisis already evident will become worse this year;
—Its scandalous allocation to International Co-Operation, which now represents the smallest proportion of GNP of any year since 1980.”
—(Deputy Spring.)
Amendment put.
The Dáil divided: Tá, 20; Níl, 74.

MainHeading.Title: Private Members' Business. - Services for the Mentally Handicapped: Motion.

Speaker.P: We have lost 15 minutes, Deputy, which may be taken another time. The Deputy has 40 minutes to move the motion.
With the agreement of the House, I wish to share some of my time with Deputy Deenihan.
Is that satisfactory? Agreed.
I move:

That Dáil Éireann deplores the lack of Government planning and provision of adequate services for mentally handicapped persons; calls on the Minister for Health to provide adequate residential, day-care and community care facilities for all age groups of mental handicap and to bring forward legislative proposals to give specific legal rights to such disabled persons.

In total there are some 100,000 handicapped people in this country. Of these, 23,000 are mentally handicapped. There are four categories of mental handicap: mild, moderate, severe and profound. Most significantly, of those who are handicapped 850 become adults each year. We have seriously neglected adult mentally handicapped persons who are living at home with ageing, geriatric or dying parents. The crisis they face is that there is little or no prospect of finding residential places for those adult mentally handicapped persons. The parents' greatest anxiety and fear is that after they die there will be nowhere for handicapped persons to go. That is a very big burden for those people to carry to the grave. Having minded their children all their lives there is no prospect of finding a place for them now.

MainHeading.P: When we examine the statistics we find that at present in the Dublin area alone there is urgent need for 330 residential places, and there is a need for an extra 800 residential places for adults generally. It is quite obvious that the Government have no overall plan to provide for the special needs of mentally handicapped persons. When we take a look at the current climate in relation to the provision of services and Government policy we see that resources have been frozen and curtailed in real terms, that staff numbers have been severely restricted and that families with members who are mentally handicapped face the future with uncertainty and fear. Not only do we not have extra resources to meet extra needs, but the number of persons with mental handicap are increasing and they also have an increased life expectancy. Fine Gael are proposing an integrated five year investment plan to meet those needs. This would include the provision of extra residential places, a national provision for day care centres, adequate places for vocational training and adequate respite facilities for families plus a wide range of ancillary specialist services.

It is absolutely vital that we now look at the statistics in relation to need. One of the big problems has been the absence of proper statistics. Through the work of the central planning committee of the Eastern Health Board we now have a proper assessment. I accept that there were people on a waiting list to get into St. Michael's House, St. John of God's and other centres, but we now have accurate State figures as to the need in the Dublin region. The EHB cover 40 per cent of the population and provide the best service. The service deteriorates once one moves outside of the Pale. According to the figures, there is a need for 29 residential places for children in the EHB area. In terms of adults and adolescents there is a need for 253 places.

We have a total of 16,000 mentally handicapped persons of all ages living in family settings. The quality of their lives depends not only on the loving environment in their homes but on the dignity they acquire through day time activities so that they can lead full and active lives. They should be able to go to a day centre where they can receive therapy that will improve their wellbeing and welfare. The waiting list for day care centres comprises 57 children and 334 adults and adolescents. It is estimated that the financial resources required by the EHB amount to £7 million — £2 million capital and £5 million for current uses. These are the figures of the central planning committee, they are not my figures. They are very telling and they relate only to the requirement for 1989-90.

One must ask what will be the position in the future. All of these mentally handicapped people are already in society and their parents are getting older. Figures of residential places in the EHB area between now and 1992 show the need for a startling 1,645 additional residential places. I inquired how many places had been provided this year in the EHB area and to the best of my information I found that only five additional places have been provided in the Dublin area this year in St. Michael's House. The discrepancy between what the Minister is doing and the requirement is incomprehensible, and it is no wonder that the Parents' Association for the Mentally Handicapped will be taking to the streets this Friday to protest to this House at the inaction of the Government.

The quality of life for the mentally handicapped at home depends on access to specialist centres on a daily basis. It is estimated that some 360 day places are now required for the Dublin area and 1,000 such places are required nationally. There is a total of 6,000 people with mental handicap living in the community in the EHB area. The establishment of an integrated set of services for the mentally handicapped, based on guidelines laid down by the Department of Health, to be operated in each health board area is essential. This would include day care centres with the back-up facilities of speech therapists and physiotherapists. In relation to speech therapists, it is undoubtedly the case, given that mental handicap cannot be cured, that of all the specialist services, speech therapy can be of enormous benefit. I know that some cases are waiting three years before they are even assessed. I know of one child who had speech therapy for a couple of years and then there was a break of two and a half years with no speech therapy although the child was responding very well to speech therapy. This is unacceptable.

The Minister commissioned a report on communication needs, a discussion document on needs and services for people with mental handicap in Ireland. The foreword of the report was written by the Minister this year. The working party report, in their recommendations on speech therapy, stated that there should be an additional 371 speech therapists appointed and they recommended that there should be the immediate creation of 20 new posts each year for the next three years. It is obvious that all the other recommendations in the report pale into insignificance when the central recommendation of additional manpower is neglected.

The research, career structure, guidelines, therapy assessment, intervention and the setting up of multi-disciplinary teams are Utopian in relation to what is provided in the 1990 Estimates. There is no point commissioning an expert analysis of the situation to assess the speech therapy and communication needs and then leaving the report to gather dust. In a national integrated plan, we envisage adequate physiotherapy and speech therapy services. A standard component of the community care element of our services requires that there should be monitoring and assessment units involving the local director of community care, the National Rehabilitation Board and a consumer input from the parents of mentally handicapped persons based in each catchment area.

Genetic counselling is not available on a regional basis, and it should be. There is a lot of talk about preventive medicine but nothing has been done in this area. I have heard of parents who have not been told professionally and diplomatically in the early days after a baby is born that the child is mentally handicapped. It is vital to have experts to counsel parents in these situations. If families are to cope in a community care setting we must urgently put in place proper counselling facilities. If we talk about providing comprehensive care for the mentally handicapped we are not just talking about the Department of Health. The needs of mental handicap extend beyond the duties of the Department of Health.

There are some crazy anomalies in our social welfare code. If one is a mentally handicapped person one is entitled to a free travel pass, that is very important, but there is a catch in that one can only use one's free travel pass if one is accompanied by a spouse. How many mentally handicapped persons have spouses? Surely if there was any charity in the system, we would allow that a mentally handicapped person would only have to be accompanied by a companion instead of a spouse to avail of the benefits of a free travel pass.

In that regard also, under the law, a mentally handicapped person is entitled to a free travel pass only on reaching 16 years of age. I cannot understand why a mentally handicapped infant is not entitled to free travel. A particular grievance in relation to that — and perhaps the Minister would address this because it is directly within his own control — is that a mentally handicapped person is, on his 16th birthday, automatically entitled to a medical card irrespective of means. Surely, on compassionate grounds again, a medical card should be issued at birth because the most serious expense in relation to medicines and GP visits etc. occurs in the formative years. I ask the Minister to amend that to ensure that mentally handicapped people get these benefits at an earlier stage.

Also, in relation to the social welfare code the position is that if a mentally handicapped person is taken into a residential centre he is given not one penny of pocket money, irrespective of means. Some small amount of disabled person's maintenance allowance should be paid to those mentally handicapped persons who are in residential homes.

The principal social welfare benefit we have for mentally handicapped children in the community is the domiciliary care allowance. Unlike other social welfare payments this has not kept pace with inflation and is at a very meagre rate. I ask the Government to reconsider this and increase it and, in the case of mentally handicapped persons, to abolish the annual medical test, because it is patently obvious that those people are not going to get better.

There is a real crisis developing in relation to the educational needs of the handicapped. Some years ago there were attendants and assistants in the class with the special teachers. There was a ratio of 12 pupils to one teacher. With the cutbacks the attendants have gone, the assistants have gone and the teachers are left to manage on their own. Because of the cutbacks and restrictions there are groupings of the more severely and even profoundly handicapped children in the same small class as those with mild and moderate handicap. This is totally unacceptable and restricts the educational opportunities for those children.

In the motion we make reference to the legal rights of the mentally handicapped. Currently those legal rights are inadequate. The Health Acts do not give the handicapped the right to service. Under law it is stated that a health board “shall provide” certain services. That has been interpreted by CEOs in health boards as meaning that maybe they will provide the services and maybe they will not, according to the financial constraints on them. It is absolutely true that there is no civil right of mentally handicapped persons to medical services. They are dependent on vague generalities as to the provision of care. This, essentially, means that the quality of service, the access to service depends on what part of the country one lives in. Access to speech therapy and physiotherapy services clearly depends on where one lives and how extensive the health board's services are in that area. It is unacceptable that we do not have a standard of health care that is enforceable across the country.

In relation to the law, we should introduce a system of guardianship where appropriate for mentally handicapped adults who have lost their parents. I am thinking of a mentally handicapped adult in his thirties or forties in a residential home whose parents are deceased, where there is nobody to look after his best interests, nobody to be consulted. The Down's Syndrome Association have lobbied for it, and it is only reasonable that we establish a legal system of guardianship for adult mentally handicapped persons.

I wish to turn to the important area relating to the moderate and mildly handicapped and their need for human dignity, their need for employment, for training. Right across this country we have a proud tradition and an excellent record of rehabilitation centres, of community workshops and other vocational training centres that do an excellent job. It is a source of great regret to me that our mainline services, formally AnCO, the National Manpower Service and now FÁS have totally washed their hands of the disabled. They are just not interested. This work has fallen mostly on voluntary bodies such as the community workshops and Rehab.

The problem is twofold. First there is a huge waiting list to get into community workshops. People who have come out of schools at 17, 18 and 19 years of age are sitting at home doing nothing when they could usefully be involved in community workshops. However, there are no places available because there are no opportunities in open employment for the people who have completed the training in the community workshops. The system of funding is through the European Social Fund. There is a grant for five years for participants in the community workshops but after the five years the money ends. Because there are no employment opportunities for these people after the five years they are staying in the community workshop so that there are no new places to let in new entrants. This is a critical situation for these adolescents and young people who are at home and quite capable of participating but who have no opportunity to do so.

There is only one solution. The Minister has a golden opportunity now, coming into Ireland's Presidency of the European Council of Minister on 1 January. Ireland should take an initiative to ensure that sheltered employment and participation in sheltered employment projects get ESF funding. We have only one centre for sheltered employment here — and by sheltered employment I mean subsidised work that is, perhaps, up to the productivity of one-third of industrial performance and that needs an economic subsidy. We have one centre in this country for the blind which is quite costly but we need a national programme which, given Exchequer constraints, can only be found by ESF funding. We should take the initiative in this area and seek ESF funding for sheltered employment. That is absolutely vital.

There are other recommendations in the report on training and employing the handicapped. It is a lovely document with some very worthy analyses and some excellent recommendations. It clearly says that there should be, at local level, integration between the national rehabilitation board, FÁS and the director of Community Care to establish a register of persons who are suitable for training in sheltered employment, that would assess them, place them appropriately and monitor their performance thereafter. The establishment of proper activation and training centres is the way to go. It is not good enough to give mentally handicapped young people a special education either integrated into the overall education system or in a special school up to 18 years of age, put them on a waiting list and after that basically forget about them. We need to maintain education services beyond 18 years of age and make available some 3,000 or 4,000 extra places in sheltered employment. That would have a very beneficial effect on the whole community.

There are a number of specific areas that I would like to refer to briefly as it often takes a specific case to highlight a situation. Most of the centres dealing with the handicapped across the country are facing severe restrictions at present. When we scrutinise the 1990 Estimate we will see that, at best, extra money is being made available to meet the inflationary demands of pay and so on but if we make a closer analysis of the extra £111 million that has been granted in the health Vote in 1990, what do we see? The extra £15 million for our acute hospital programme, the decision to keep beds open during the summer, the decision as regards accidents and emergency services in Dublin and Mullingar hospitals, apply to the last quarter of this year. Multiply those by four for the cost of those policy decisions in a full year and throw in pay increases, and we find the health budget for 1990 is some £35 million short of meeting the real needs. That is without improving in any way the needs of a component such as the services for the mentally handicapped. Instead of an increase of £111 million, when we annualise the cost of the policy decisions taken in the last quarter of this year we find after inflation, after medical inflation, after all the built-in added costs, we are £35 million short on the opening position in 1989. A great misconception has been created that the health crisis is over. The health crisis is alive and well, unfortunately, and will linger as long as this Government remain in office.

As is the case with so many areas such as the dental policy that we have discussed here, there is no stated policy for the mentally handicapped. There is no stated policy on the input of all the different components of training day care and residential care. We have no norm set down of so many per thousand of the population put in place. We are dependent on the crumbs from the national lottery for mental handicap on a hand to mouth basis over recent years. The 23,000 people in this country who are mentally handicapped because they are so voiceless and vulnerable deserve much better than to be dependent simply on the lottery.

We need a special sex education programme for adolescents with mental handicap because they perhaps could be more vulnerable to sexual abuse than any other group. Within our education system and our specialist education system we need a national educational psychologist service for all children attending to get the proper assessment.

In relation to paediatric nursing we need special revision for their training incorporating the work of An Bord Altranais to deal with the specialist needs of the mentally handicapped. That, with a comprehensive costing service, would form the basis of what is required.

I am aware that this is a somewhat truncated debate by virtue of the votes and, as I said, I wish to share my time with Deputy Jimmy Deenihan and I will summarise as follows. For the last half dozen years we have had a freezing of resources for the mentally handicapped. We have been told that within the overall context of the health cutbacks the services for the mentally handicapped have been protected. This is a not true. Services have not been maintained, and at a time when there are increasing numbers, increased life expectancy and increased demand, no provision has been made in a planned way to provide the extra 800 residential places now required and double that within the next three years, and the 1,000 extra day care places required across the country. We have made no arrangements to put in place with those mainline and residential day care places the back-up services of speech therapy, physiotherapy and counselling. No steps have been taken to integrate a system of assessment and monitoring for mentally handicapped places. There has been no new initiative in relation to vocational training and sheltered employment.

All in all there is a crisis of neglect. There is a predictable need. We are not talking about an epidemic, something like the AIDS virus that is beyond technology at this stage in terms of a cure. We are dealing with an inevitable and predictable need of the most vulnerable and voiceless section of our community. The parents and families of this sector are now saying that enough is enough. They have carried this on their backs for so long and now extra money is being made available for the health services in Supplementary Estimates this year, and next year there is no extra provision for the mentally handicapped. I appeal to all sides of this House to support this motion and I hope, arising out of this debate, we will have a five year investment plan and policy strategy put in place to ensure that the mentally handicapped are no longer the forgotten Cinderella sector of our health services but are put in their rightful place at the top of the political agenda.

Speaker.P: Deputy Jimmy Deenihan sharing the time of Deputy Yates. The Deputy is due to conclude at 7.56 p.m.

As one who had experience in working with the handicapped for a time before I came into this House I can identify with the call by the parents and friends of the mentally handicapped for a better deal. I can also understand their feeling of hopelessness and the feeling they are being let down and ignored by the present system and the present Government. If one looks at the progress made in the early eighties and compares it with recent progress one can understand fully that these people have every right to be frustrated and to feel bad about it.

MainHeading.P: As Deputy Yates pointed out, there is an urgent and immediate need for an additional 328 residential places and 360 day places in the greater Dublin area alone. Nationwide approximately 800 residential places and more than 1,000 day places are required. The organisatìons, most of which are voluntary, providing services for persons with a mental handicap cannot cope with this huge demand. The problem is just basic lack of resources and finance. Many of the persons with a mental handicap are with specialist training able to acquire vocational and social skills. This enhances their dignity and sense of self worth. As a result the quality of life for persons with a mental handicap and their families is greatly improved. Many have the ability to be trained for open employment and are then in a position to contribute to the economy. Others will thrive as employees in supported enterprise type ventures. An activation programme will benefit other. The funding crisis has halted the development of suitable programmes for such people. Roughly these programmes can be divided as follows. As regards training, specific work skills and general social skills are required by trainees with a view to competing for and holding down a job in the open labour market. Training takes place in vocational training programmes and in pre-vocational post-school programmes. These programmes are totally curtailed at the moment and the resources are not there to expand them. They gave the opportunity for all our handicapped people who would fit into this category an opportunity to improve themselves and expand their personalities.

Community-based enterprises can be established successfully to give long-term, meaningful employment to persons with more limited ability. While some enterprises can be commercially viable, many will require financial support. Again, the people involved in providing enterprises, especially community-based enterprises, for handicapped people are curtailed in their efforts by basic lack of resources. They could do far more and they are crying out for more resources in order to provide more enterprises for this most vulnerable section of our population.

Community-based activation units can increase greatly the quality of life for persons whose capacity to work is limited. The focus of these programmes is on recreation and social skills. The possibility for community-based activation units again is greatly curtailed by the lack of resources. Because of cutbacks and lack of resources many persons with a mental handicap are sitting at home living lives of poor quality and are often an emotional and economic drain on their parents and siblings. Were additional resources available many of these people could take part in a meaningful day programme which would not cost very much. Frequently the buildings are already available but more funding is needed to pay staff and running costs. Certainly, this is the case in my own county of Kerry.

I would like to refer briefly to the problems in Kerry, with which I am most familiar. The biggest crisis involves those over 18 years of age. There are no services available on demand for people leaving school. The facilities are there but the resources are not available to provide additional staff to operate the facilities. We have one of the finest facilities in Ireland in Tralee which is managed by the St. John of God Brothers, but they do not have the human resources to keep it open long enough and to operate a number of programmes which they could if they had the resources. Middle age handicapped people living with aging or single parents are particularly vulnerable. Deputy Yates singled out this group specifically. There are about 60 people in this category in County Kerry alone. Over the next five years these people will be looking for residential care. As Deputy Yates rightly pointed out, the major fear among old people who have handicapped children is what will happen to them when they are dead. There are no seven day residential care facilities for handicapped people in County Kerry except St. Finian's Hospital. As the Minister has often pointed out, it is stated Government policy that handicapped people should not be admitted to psychiatric hospitals.

Speaker.P: Hear, hear.

Here we are in County Kerry with no facilities to cater for this most vulnerable section of our population. The voluntary agencies are prepared to co-ordinate efforts to provide the necessary service if given the resources. I would point out here that the grant given to the parents and friends of the mentally handicapped in County Kerry by the Southern Health Board this year was derisory and an insult to their work and efforts on behalf of the handicapped in the county. In Listowel at present the Department of Education are building a special school for the handicapped — I welcome the initiative — which will take over from the Nano Nagle school for the handicapped in Lixnaw. By some strange coincidence the school for the handicapped is being located upstairs whereas a local primary school is downstairs. Surely it would have been far better planning if the school for the handicapped was located downstairs. To add insult to what was already a grave injustice, they have refused to provide funding for a lift for this school; in other words, the parents and friends of the handicapped in County Kerry will have to provide, from their own resources, funds for this lift. This is showing a total disrespect for the handicapped people in our county. I appeal to the Minister to take up this matter with the Minister for Education. The cost involved is £36,000; not a huge cost. It is only right that this lift should be totally or partially funded by the Department of Education.

As Deputy Yates said, we need a clear definite policy from the Government on the future development of educational and health services for the mentally handicapped in Ireland. This is an immediate and urgent priority. Such a policy should be formulated in consultation with all the voluntary agencies, the various health board workers, teachers, parents and friends of the mentally handicapped at all levels and all those other people involved with the handicapped.

Research is urgently needed to determine the nature and extent of the overall education and health problems of mentally handicapped people, otherwise planning will continue to take place on an ad hoc basis as at present. The Minister has a constitutional obligation to cherish all the children of this country equally. I call on him to exercise his responsibility on behalf of this most vulnerable section of our community.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: Before dealing with my amendment I want to deal with one point raised by Deputy Yates and I will come back to other points raised by him as we progress. He stated that in the £11 million extra gross there was no money for any development whatsoever and he said the £15 million which was spent in a quarter in the acute hospitals became £60 million for a full year. The reality is that it becomes £34 million for a full year. As the Deputy is well aware, I have given a breakdown many times of the £15 million and some of it was for equipment which is a non-recurring expense. This is the sort of arithmetic that got the Coalition into trouble and they grossly over spent during the years they were in office——
With your help.
Which Coalition?
Everyone knows the one that put the £55 million under the carpet.
That was the health boards.
It was Barry Desmond.

I would ask the Minister to formally move his amendment. After that we will be asking that Deputies, especially in respect of the subject we are discussing, exercise some restraint and listen to each other from whichever side. If they do not I shall have to remind them of the consequences.
I move amendment No. 1:
To delete all words after “Dáil Éireann” and substitute the following:

Commends the reports of the Minister for Health to improve the level of services available to mentally handicapped persons despite the severe overall limitations on Exchequer resources and the intention to make further resources available for the development of these services as budgetary circumstances permit.

May I say first of all that I am fully conscious of and sensitive to the needs and fears of the families of mentally handicapped people, as evidenced in the considerable debate and publicity which is accorded to this general subject.

MainHeading.P: I am glad to have the opportunity to put on the record the Government's policy in relation to mental handicap services. In summary, this policy aims to ensure that services appropriate to their requirements are available to people with mental handicap and specifically, that the necessary support services are made available to enable persons with mental handicap to live as normal a life as possible.

While few would question that this policy is correct, some may question, however, whether there is a gap between the policy and the service on the ground. I recognise the gaps and I fully accept that there are further developments in the services required to bring about the full realisation of the aspirations of that policy. Neither do I underestimate the challenge in achieving that result in financial and, indeed, in attitudinal terms. I do not accept, however, that the service has been at a standstill over the recent past. Significant improvements have taken place during the past three years. My priority is to ensure that the pace of these improvements is accelerated.

To put this problem into perspective the Government are spending about £130 million on services for people with a mental handicap in the current year, this is about 10 per cent of total public spending on all health services or about 22 per cent of what we spend on acute hospital services. Indeed, Deputy Yates suggested twice that the amount of money being provided was frozen over the last number of years but that is not the case. There has been quite a substantial increase in the amount of money provided over the last three years. Other services had their allocation reduced but that did not happen in the case of services for the mentally handicapped.

As soon as mental handicap is suspected in the case of an infant, referral is made to the appropriate local agency, voluntary or health board, for detailed assessment and advice and support to parents. Thereafter a range of services is available. About 2,400 families get domiciliary care allowance of £79 per month for mentally handicapped children, at a total cost of £2.2 million. At age 16 the young adult is eligible for disabled person's allowance, maximum £47.20 per week. Up to 8,000 mentally handicapped persons are in receipt of this allowance, about one third of the total number of recipients of the allowance.

There are 53 special residential centres catering for 4,679 persons, 210 hostels with 1,205 residents, 80 day care centres catering for 1,967 persons and 90 training centres with 3,309 places. The 90 training centres came on stream since the publication of the Robins' report in the seventies and it is an indication that my predecessors and I have worked to implement as many of the recommendations of the report as possible. There is a steady programme of location of persons with a mental handicap from the psychiatric institutions to more appropriate settings. There are now fewer than 1,600 residents in such institutions but, pending their transfer, special units within the hospitals are being designated for them and appropriate programmes implemented.

To continue our economic development a restraint on public spending needs to continue. I am sure the House accepts that the only way to develop our social services on any sort of a sound basis is to make sure that we can produce the finance for that purpose through a healthy economy. The House has seen the value of the Government's policies over the last two and a half years. As a result of this, health spending, unfortunately, cannot be radically increased over the next few years. Close management of the funds will be necessary to cater for the needs of people as they arise.

I have, therefore, taken positive steps to meet this challenge. To do so requires that in my planning I must ensure that all funds allocated to me are distributed carefully to ensure the greatest return, ensuring the best quality of service to the people in need. I must also ensure that where additional funds become available, people in greatest need of services have priority. To do this requires two things. Firstly, it requires accurate information on individual needs, and secondly, it requires agreement between service providers, statutory and voluntary, as to how those needs will be met. These, essentially, are the reasons behind my decision to reactivate the regional mental handicap co-ordinating committees in each health board area.

The main function of these committees is the development, implementation and monitoring of a plan of services for their respective health board areas in which statutory and voluntary agencies co-ordinate their services. This includes not only agreement on such matters as catchment areas and content of services to be provided by each agency to ensure no overlapping of duplication occurs. It also requires rationalisation of services, the determination of, and planning to provide for, unmet needs.

I know this is not an easy task. It is not easy to agree on the degree of priority of one proposal relative to another. All proposals have their merits and I can assure the House there is no shortage of proposals. Indeed, Deputy Yates referred tonight to an excellent report on speech therapy. I did not commission the report, it was produced by a special interest group in speech therapy for the mentally handicapped and they are based in Galway. It is an objective report and it points out the needs in the area of speech therapy. The reports stated that 371 speech therapists are necessary but it is fair to make the point that that requirement did not just become necessary in the past two-and-a-half years, it has been there for many years. Perhaps there was not a need for 371 speech therapists but many were needed and we will be looking into that area. This highlights the value of the co-ordinating committee who will be able to decide on the priority needs in the various areas. I know that decisions on priorities are difficult but they must be made. It would, as I have said, be unrealistic to expect resources to meet all demands immediately. Good choices must be made if the best value is to be obtained from what we have. In general, our first priority must be to provide services to people who currently have either no service or a completely inadequate one. This must involve the use of all the resources which are available to the sector, including the use for capital purposes of resources collected from private sources. All resources should be used to ensure the thrust of the overall policy.

The work of the co-ordinating committees has advanced more quickly in some areas than in others. I have been particularly impressed by the work of the co-ordinating committee in the Eastern Health Board region. The committee identified a wide variety of unmet needs for individuals. These range from children and adults with no day services, shortage of crisis intervention respite care facilities and shortages of residential facilities.

This committee have now provided me with hard information on the needs of people with mental handicap in the Eastern Health Board area, backed by cost estimates and a blueprint for meeting these needs. The committee's proposals, together with proposals from other areas are being considered by me and I hope to be in a position to respond to them in a positive way in the near future.

I have always been happy to acknowledge the significance of the role played by the voluntary organisations in the provision of services for the disabled people and in ensuring that the quality of the care provided is fully in line with modern thinking about the needs of these people and the obligations of society to meet them.

We are particularly fortunate that we had the core of the services long before the health boards were developed, due mainly to the religious orders. Since the commission's report in 1965 there has been tremendous development in this country of which we can all be proud.

I am quite clear about the need for the maintenance and strengthening of the voluntary area and the importance of good relations between the voluntary and public sector in catering for handicapped persons. The reconstitution of co-ordinating committees in each health board area comprising representatives of the statutory and non-statutory bodies, including a representative of my own Department, in each case is designed to promote this mutual understanding and co-operation.

I very much regret, therefore, to have to say that my experience with Cheeverstown in the past year has been a disappointment. I dealt with this matter in my reply to a question by Deputy Flood this afternoon. However, its relevance in the context of this debate is such that I may perhaps be allowed to recapitulate.

The Cheeverstown complex was built at a cost of £8 million to play a central role in meeting an acute need for up to date provision for handicapped children and adults in the Dublin region, an area which is generally accepted to have special problems at the present time. The revenue funding of this centre is the responsibility of the Eastern Health Board, which have the statutory obligation of ensuring that there is an adequate and properly managed service for the people of their area and for seeing that these services are dispensed in the most effective and efficient manner.

It is quite reasonable, therefore — indeed it is an obligation upon them — that the health board should wish to be satisfied about the manner of operating of the agencies they fund and their contribution towards meeting the priority needs of the people on their waiting lists for residential and day places. The health board expressed themselves as dissatisfied in this regard with Cheeverstown.

I intervened in the disagreement between the board of that centre and the health board in an attempt to reach an accommodation between the two parties which would allow for due progress with the development of the badly needed facilities in this fine centre. The two criteria which I had regard to were (1) Cheeverstown should be developed to its full potential as a matter of urgency and (2) neither the Eastern Health Board nor Cheeverstown would be allowed to dominate the other.

My sole concern was to ensure that the resources allocated to Cheeverstown should be made available to those handicapped people who needed them and their hard pressed families. I also made it clear that I would not give any support to a takeover of the centre by the statutory authorities. After a series of meetings and negotiations with all of the parties involved, an interim management board was established representative of the existing Cheeverstown board, the Eastern Health Board, the voluntary sector and parents representatives under the chairmanship of former Garda Commissioner, Eamonn Doherty.

The constitution of this interim committee was such as to ensure that no one party had a predominating voice. The committee consisted of three representatives of the Eastern Health Board, three representatives of Cheeverstown, one representative of the major voluntary orders running a service for the mentally handicapped, one representative of the parents and Mr. Eamonn Doherty as chairman.

The prospect in view was that by working together in pursuance of a common aim of service to the handicapped and the full utilisation of Cheeverstown, a spirit of understanding and trust would develop which would enable the old Cheeverstown board to resume control after a year or two in an atmosphere which ensured good relations with the health board.

Unfortunately, my formula was not implemented. The old Cheeverstown board retained the running of the affairs of the centre and have refused to accept my further suggestion for an impartial board which would have been representative of the main voluntary organisations in Dublin, together with representatives from Cheeverstown itself and the health board.

I am not alone in my dissatisfaction with this state of affairs. Three members of the Cheeverstown board have already resigned in protest at the recalcitrance of its chairman and other members, and the representatives of the parents, who are so anxious to see places opened for their children, have also voiced their discontent with the attitude of Cheeverstown board. I can say that the other major voluntary organisations were not happy with the response of that board.

In short, given the identified need for places in residential accommodation I cannot any longer tolerate a situation in which there are 60 such places unused in Cheeverstown. I have initiated a certain course of action to deal with the situation, in view of the seriousness of the need for this facility to come into full use and the substantial investment of scarce and badly needed funds in its construction and running.

There is no other similar experience in other parts of the country. In fact I would like to place on record my acknowledgement of the excellent relationships which exist otherwise between the Department, the health boards and the voluntary bodies.

I mentioned the concern of parents of mentally handicapped people earlier. Deputy Yates, in his opening remarks, highlighted one such fear. A fear which is often expressed is that their mentally handicapped child or adult will not be cared for when the parents die. Such a strain and such a prospect would be intolerable and is one of the issues concerning the lives of the disabled which needs to be dealt with in an unambiguous fashion.

It is most important that a close relationship is established in every individual case with the agency in whose area of responsibility that handicapped person and his or her family are living. This will ensure that when the parents are no longer living there is the assurance that he or she will be cared for in a setting, and by people, who understand their particular needs. I believe that this is not simply an ideal but is in fact the practice in every case. If, however, there is any parent who is not satisfied that an arrangement of this kind is apparent in their case, they should contact their family doctor, the health board and my Department to assist them in establishing a satisfactory promise of continuing care for their family member. No parent should have to worry about this. I am satisfied that if a crisis arises, it would be dealt with. I am unaware, in fact, I could not envisage a situation where if the parents or a parent died or something happened suddenly that a mentally handicapped child or adult would not be looked after. In fact it has been my experience that children were taken into care and received the best of attention.

It is far from the truth to say that there have been no developments in mental handicap services in the past few years. There are now some 11,000 people with a mental handicap in receipt of day or residential services. This represents an increase of 12 per cent on the level of activity in 1985. Since 1986 the allocations to voluntary agencies funded by my Department have increased from £58 million to almost £69 million in 1989, an increase of 20 per cent.

I would like to outline some of the salient features of these developments. Approximately £500,000 has been made available to St. Vincent's centre on the Navan Road in Dublin to facilitate the movement of some 200 residents from the centre to alternative accommodation. In this connection, I must pay special tribute to the Daughters of Charity for the manner in which they responded to the urgent need which arose, following the serving of a fire notice on their premises at the Navan Road. The co-operative spirit in which the order worked with my Department in meeting this emergency was most heartening. This urgent task involved the relocation of several hundred severely handicapped people to a range of alternative facilities over a short period.

Progress in this matter has been most satisfactory from many points of view, with a substantial improvement in the quality of life of the residents concerned. This achievement is a splendid example of the flexibility and enterprise of a voluntary body who have traditionally provided an excellent caring service for people with mental handicaps. With a long tradition of providing such care in an institutional setting, the Daughters of Charity services have moved into the community with a rapidity and professionalism which sets an example for the whole country and indeed, for the rest of Europe. I have also recently conveyed my approval to a new purpose built unit on the Navan Road which will serve as the resource centre for the services provided from the St. Vincent's complex.
This unit will have facilities for respite care in addition to long term care.

St. Michael's House also received resources which enabled them to open their adult special care unit for 50 people at Belcamp. In addition they were given resources in 1988 to provide ten residential places, five of which were for short term or crisis relief. Funding was provided in 1988 to enable Phase 1 of Áras Attracta, Swinford, consisting of 66 residential places, to come into operation. There are currently 40 places occupied. When fully operational the centre will provide residential places for 140 adults and 50 children, and 60 day care places.

Important developments which have taken place in the North Eastern Health Board include the development of a special mental handicap service at Clogher House to cater for persons formerly within St. Davnets. The St. John of God Brothers provided ten hostels for 43 people. Through redeployment and rationalisation the order are also involved with the health board in expanded day services in Dundalk.
It is now accepted policy that people with mental handicap should not be admitted to mental hospitals.

Following the successful relocations of clients from a number of psychiatric hospitals, all health boards are being encouraged to have assessments carried out by the mental handicap agencies in relation to people with a mental handicap who are currently in psychiatric hospitals, with a view to providing more appropriately for their needs.

Earlier this year I provided funds for the opening of ten residential places in Dawn House, Wexford. I also provided funds to the Brothers of Charity and the Brothers of St. John of God to open hostels in Galway and Monaghan respectively.

In total over £4.8 million was paid in capital grants for mental handicap services during 1987-88 for a variety of projects, including renovations and improvements to existing facilities and development of new community facilities. In addition to the projects which I have mentioned, a further £1.5 million has been made available from the proceeds of the national lottery for the provision of community based accommodation for people in institutions and renovation work to existing facilities. A large number of agencies working with the mentally handicapped have received financial assistance from this source. For example, I have granted a total of £400,000 from the lottery to agencies working with the mentally handicapped.

Kerry Parents and Friends Association have received a grant of £100,000 as a contribution towards the development of services for the mentally handicapped in Killarney. The Brothers of Charity in Galway also received a contribution of £100,000 to assist with the development of community based services in the Galway region. In Kilkenny, the Kilkenny Association for the Mentally Handicapped received a grant of £36,000 to provide community based accommodation for young adults with severe mental handicap from St. Patrick's, Kilkenny while a further grant of £30,000 was made available to provide day space in St. Patrick's for people with multiple handicaps. KARE, the County Kildare association of parents and friends of handicapped children have also received £70,000 to date from the lottery to develop services for mentally handicapped children in the Kildare region.

In making the 1990 allocations for the mental handicap service, I will ensure that resource is available to permit of the commencement of a planned expansion of the services taking account of the changing nature of service requirements. I would like to emphasise my commitment to meeting the acknowledged needs of people with mental handicap and my determination to press ahead with the planning and development of necessary services.

The question of legislation to give specific rights to persons with mental handicap is being considered. Deputy Yates referred to this matter. I intend to engage in wide-ranging consultations with various organisations including the National Association for Mentally Handicapped of Ireland on that issue.

I will deal briefly with some of the issues raised about there having been no development in this area. For example, the hostel provision in 1985 amounted to 127 and at the end of the year 1988 there were 210 hostels, nearly double, with the number of places increasing from 773 to 1,205 residents, and an increase of 83 hostels. In 1985 there were 99 day care centres and workshops whereas, at the end of 1988, there were 170 centres, representing an increase of 71 centres with provision for 2,352 attenders. Therefore the House will note that, despite the constraints, there have been some developments of which we can be justifiably proud.
Deputy Yates referred to St. Michael's House creating five places only. I should point out that they created ten places in Ballymun alone.

Speaker.P: That was in 1988.

The 850 persons annually reaching adulthood is another tribute to the development of our services and indeed to the development of the health services generally, illustrating that more and more of our mentally handicapped are living into adulthood.

I take the point that we must be very sensitive with regard to the people who inform parents that their child is handicapped. Generally that is done in the hospitals. Also, there are now nurses trained specifically in mental handicap working in the community.

MainHeading.P: On the question of medical cards, the cost of expensive medicines and so on for the mentally handicapped, I should say that the mentally handicapped are automatically entitled to long-term illness cards. Probably the majority of them would hold medical cards but those who do not are entitled to access all of their medicines free of charge.

My colleague, the Minister for Education, will be speaking in this debate tomorrow evening. I am sure she will correct the Deputy on the matter of the reduction in the number of remedial teachers because she has stated many times in this House that those who are disadvantaged did not suffer any reduction in their number of remedial teachers.

I fully agree with the Deputy on the amount of money available from the European Social Fund, that such money should be available for sheltered workshops in the same way as it is available for training workshops. I should point out that that money was expended on sheltered workshops until 1983. We were not in power in 1983 but, in that year, there was a change, following which money from the European Social Fund was provided only for training the handicapped and not for sheltered workshops. I agree with the Deputy that if money can be made available from that fund it should be for that purpose.

Deputy Deenihan talked about there having been progress in the early eighties and none now. He gave an example of the development of the late eighties, that being the St. John of God's facility in Tralee. I will have examined the question of whether there should be a lift installed in the school in Listowel. It should be remembered that the mentally handicapped are not physically handicapped and are well able to use stairs. Indeed, we might well add to their handicap were we to encourage them to use lifts rather than stairs.

In conclusion, the calibre of the organisations of parents and others devoted to the interests of people with mental handicap is such as to ensure that none of us is allowed to forget or overlook the need for continued attention to this important area of service provision. I say to them it would be my wish to work with them and co-operate fully toward the objective of improving the quality of care of handicapped persons.

Speaker.P: The unfortunate need to oppose the Estimates for next year has resulted in a truncation of our debate this evening. It is inhibiting to begin a contribution on a subject as important as this knowing I will be interrupted in approximately three minutes.
At the outset I should like to indicate that I wish to share my time with Deputy Garland tomorrow evening if that is acceptable to the House.
We must put that formally to the House. Does the House agree? Agreed.
I also give the House notice that I propose to make the following amendment No. 2 to the motion in the names of members of the Labour Party which I now read into the record:
To add to the Motion:
Dáil Éireann endorses the United Nations Convention on the Rights of persons with a mental handicap; and calls for legislation to enshrine those rights. Dáil Éireann notes with alarm that:

—According to the most reliable estimates, 328 residential places are required for persons with a mental handicap in the Eastern Health Board area alone, and they are needed immediately, with a further 567 places needed in the years after 1990;
—At least 1,000 residential places are needed in the country as a whole;
—The special national schools for persons with a mental handicap are under-staffed and under-funded;

—There is an acute shortage of training places available for persons leaving special national schools, with the consequence that many are on waiting lists, and others have to travel long distances for training;

MainHeading.P: —Many of the support services, such as breakaway services and crisis
intervention, are in danger of collapse for lack of adequate funding;
—There are fewer and fewer employment opportunities for persons with a mental handicap, either in open or in sheltered employment.

Dáil Éireann further notes that neither the Estimates for 1990 nor the Public Capital Programme contain any additional allocation for new services or facilities for persons with a mental handicap, and that an immediate substantial allocation of resources is required in terms of both capital and current expenditure. In deploring the lack of Government planning and provision in this area, Dáil Éireann considers that the parents and families of persons with a mental handicap have the right to be involved and represented in all planning for the future.

The Labour Party will be vigorously endorsing and supporting the Fine Gael Private Members' motion this week on the subject of mental handicap. I commend Deputy Yates and the Fine Gael Party on having identified this subject as one of tremendous importance and on having identified this time as opportune for a full-scale debate in this House on this issue.

Since we tabled a motion on this subject ourselves some two months ago a great deal of information has come to light about hardship in this area caused directly by Government policy. That is why we have tabled such a comprehensive amendment to the Fine Gael motion, aimed at highlighting some specific aspects of what is now a growing crisis. Hopefully, both the motion and the amendment I have read into the record will receive cross-party support.

This Government, together with their immediate predecessors, are primarily responsible for the cutbacks which have affected this most vulnerable section of our community. As we participate in this debate this evening the Minister and Members of this House will be aware that a meeting of the parents of people with mental handicap is taking place a short distance away in the Mansion House. That meeting is motivated by a growing sense of anger among parents, anger that is caused by the way in which they and their children have been patronised and ignored, anger at the way in which the rights of people with a mental handicap have been trampled on in recent years. The conveners of that meeting have released a press statement. The organisation is called the Parents' Association for People with a Mental Handicap and their press statement adequately sums up the case I wish to make. I look forward to reading the contents of that press statement into the record tomorrow night.
Debate adjourned.

MainHeading.Title: Supplementary Estimates, 1989. - Vote 32: Agriculture and Food.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Dr. O'Hanlon) Rory O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: I move:

That a supplementary sum not exceeding £26,110,000 be granted to defray the charge which will come in course of payment during the year ending on the 31st day of December, 1989, for the salaries and expenses of the Office of the Minister for Agriculture and Food, including certain services administered by that Office, and of the Irish Land Commission, and for payment of certain subsidies and sundry grants-in-aid.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Agriculture and Food (Mr. Kirk) Minister of State at the Department of Agriculture and Food (Mr. Kirk)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Agriculture and Food (Mr. Kirk)
Speaker.P: As Deputies are aware, Minister O'Kennedy is unable to be with us today. In his unavoidable absence the privilege rests with me of introducing this very significant Supplementary Estimate.

The net amount to be voted is a sum of £26,110,000. This consists of an additional sum of £21,830,000 for various subheads of expenditure, plus a deficiency of £18,445,000 in appropriations in aid, less savings on a number of expenditure subheads totalling £14,165,000.

MainHeading.P: I propose to follow the traditional approach by speaking on the main subheads, that is on those subheads in excess of £1,000,000 where additional expenditure or deficiencies in receipts or expenditures savings arise.
On the expenditure side I will begin with subhead B.4 where I am happy to be able to provide an additional £8 million for Teagasc this year.

The Government's main objective in setting up Teagasc was to ensure better co-ordination and cost effectiveness in the operation of the agricultural advisory, training and research services. The legislation places a special emphasis on the training of young farmers and on food research, matters to which this Government attach great importance.

On the one hand our young farmers need to be at least as well trained as their international competitors and on the other hand the raw materials they produce should be processed to the maximum extent possible to provide maximum returns.

In combining the considerable resources of the former An Foras Talúntais and ACOT under a high calibre authority and a strong unified management, the Government's objective was to deliver the agricultural research, training and advisory services in the most efficient and cost-effective way possible. I am heartened by the manner in which Teagasc have set about reorganising and restructuring the services and much has been achieved in their first year of operation. They are now well on the way to becoming a streamlined organisation with greater commercial orientation, capable of meeting the current and future needs of the agriculture and food sectors. In this way, Teagasc can greatly assist our major industry in responding to the challenges of the nineties.

In order to undertake the various activities, it is essential that the finances of Teagasc should be put on a sound footing. This £8 million will ensure that Teagasc end the year with a clean slate and can plan for a balanced budget in future years.

I turn now to subhead C2 — bovine tuberculosis and brucellosis eradication — where I am providing an additional £4 million to cover increased expenditure by ERAD. Deputies will be well aware of the determined way in which ERAD are tackling the problem of disease eradication. By bringing together all interested parties to accelerate the eradication of bovine TB and brucellosis, ERAD are proving to be a successful initiative that has resulted in a dynamic coherent and forward-looking approach to the eradication of the diseases. In the course of 1989, the board of ERAD formulated a comprehensive strategy for the eradication of bovine TB and brucellosis, the primary thrust of which was to increase the reactor extraction rate, with particular emphasis on those sources acting as persistent reservoirs of disease in the national herd. Intensive testing for TB has resulted in the identification of in excess of 37,500 reactors in almost 10.7 million tests to date, an outcome fully in accordance with the target of the eradication drive for the year. With regard to brucellosis, a full monitor of the national herd has been undertaken to guarantee the continued officially brucellosis free status of the national herd. Brucellosis testing comprises approximately 2.1 million individual blood tests on eligible animals in addition to bulk milk ring testing of all dairying herds at six week intervals during the year. Earlier this year, agreement was reached with the farming organisations that an additional £8 million, to be funded jointly by Exchequer contributions and increased levies, would be provided for the years 1989 and 1990 to cover increases in grants paid under the eradication schemes. Of the additional £4 million required for 1989, £3.106 million will be provided through savings from the 1988 allocation. I have recently made an order under the Bovine Diseases (Levies) Act, 1979 increasing the rates of levy payable.

There is a link between this subhead C2 and a particular Appropriations-in-Aid Subhead M8 — receipts from farmer contributions towards the cost of eradicating bovine disease — where, due to an 11 per cent reduction in the numbers of cattle slaughterings at meat export premises, the levy receipts will not reach the estimated amount of £22 million. It is expected that a shortfall of £900,000 will result. The estimated levy receipts are now £21.1 million.

As regards subhead L1 — farm, improvement programme, farm modernisation scheme and western measures — there is an additional rquirement of £8 million for various schemes aimed at encouraging on-farm investment as well as such measures as the young farmers' installation premium.

This year the demand for grants under these schemes has exceeded the budgetary allocation and the additional amount is required to meet the additional claims that are likely to mature between now and the end of the year.

This high level of demand is encouraging. It is an indication that farmers are investing heavily in improving the efficiency of their enterprises. They are thus expressing their confidence in the future of the industry. This investment also has important spinoff effects locally. The demand it generates for materials and services creates valuable employment in rural areas.

I am glad to say that much of this investment relates to measures to control farmyard pollution. This is in response to the very attractive grants which were introduced for this purpose in the past two years. Last year we succeeded in getting the EC to approve a scheme providing for grants of up to 55 per cent for animal housing, fodder storage and waste disposal facilities in the disadvantaged areas. Seventy per cent of the cost is funded by the EC. This year I got this scheme extended to the whole country.

The protection of the environment is vital, not alone for aesthetic reasons but from the point of view of the national economy as well. The image of a clean unspoilt environment is a major factor in boosting our tourist industry. It also helps to sell our agricultural products abroad. It is important therefore that it is not damaged. I think that the majority of farmers are realising their responsibilities in this respect and are taking the necessary precautions. With the level of grant aid now available there is no excuse for any farmer not undertaking the investment required to ensure that his farming activities are environmentally friendly.

There is a link between this subhead and a particular Appropriations-in-Aid subhead, M18 where there are additional EC receipts of £9,580,000. These receipts were originally estimated at £9,980,000 but are now expected to amount to £19,560,000. The improved receipts are due to a supplementary sum of £8 million which was approved in the Supplementary Estimate 1988 and which was spent last year, together with the maximisation of EC advance payments this year.

There are a couple of other expenditure subheads in the structural area — L10 and L11 — where, although the extra amounts involved are less than £1 million, it would be appropriate to give some explanations.

An additional £180,000 is required on the original Estimate of £400,000 under subhead L10 for the operation of the pilot programme for integrated rural development. Expenditure covers the cost of the salaries of the 12 co-ordinators who were appointed to the 12 pilot areas throughout the country, their office and administration expenses, the costs of engaging training and design consultants, conducting workshops and of providing a limited amount of funding for feasibility studies on projects which are emerging. The EC Commission recently agreed to increase its contribution to the cost of the programme to 75 per cent. The programme is advancing according to plan and the results to date are quite encouraging. It represents a very important stage in devising a national programme for the development of all rural areas.

In so far as subhead L 11 — set aside of land — is concerned it is mandatory on member states to implement the Community's scheme for the set-aside of agricultural land. The estimate for this item was prepared at a time when the EC Commission had not decided on the full details of how the measure would operate so that a token provision had to be made. An additional amount of £163,000 is now required to meet payments to participants in the scheme this year.

As regards the deficiencies in Appropriations-in-aid, the main deficiency arises under subhead M22 — receipts from the EC in respect of market intervention expenses. The Department of Agriculture and Food are the designated EC intervention agency for Ireland and, as such, purchase such products as beef, dairy products and cereals in order to support producer prices. The capital involved to make these purchases is borrowed by the Department. The Department also arrange for the necessary handling, transport and storage of these commodities. In turn, the EC makes payments to the Department in respect of all these operations at rates which are standard for all member states.

The drop of £15 million, from £61,625,000 to £46,625,000, is due primarily to lower stock levels than were originally anticipated. This in turn resulted in reduced EC receipts. The other two subheads where deficiencies arise are subheads M25 and M28. Subhead M25 provides for receipts from the United Kingdom Government in respect of the special premium on exports of beef to the United Kingdom. The scheme concerned was terminated on 2 April and as a result receipts will be £13.75 million below the amount originally provided for in the Vote. As indicated in the Supplementary Estimate there will be corresponding savings of £13.75 million in expenditure under Subhead L.7 and so the overall effect on the Vote will be neutral. The abolition of the scheme was part of the reform of the EC beef regime and coincided with an increase in the level of the suckler cow premium from £37 per head to some £52 per head. The suckler premium is paid directly to producers in all areas and, in my view, the increase will encourage expansion in the national breeding herd. A year ago we saw the first increase in the breeding herd since the introduction of the milk quota regime in 1984. This trend was confirmed by the June livestock enumeration, which showed an increase of some 64,000 head compared with June 1988. The increase occurred despite some decline in dairy cow numbers and I look forward to seeing an increased supply of calves coming on-stream in the run-up to 1992.

Receipts from meat inspection fees collected by my Department are credited to subhead M28. Receipts in 1989 are expected to be £1.1 million below the amount provided in the original Estimate. This reflects the reduced level of cattle slaughterings for much of the year and the fact that some provisions of an EC directive on meat inspection fees will now be implemented next year. I commend this Supplementary Estimate to the House.

Speaker.P: First, I want to respond by saying that I am delighted to see that £26 million is being provided in this Estimate. I will have some fairly hard words to say as to why part of this money has not been paid already nevertheless I welcome the Estimate. There was an under-provision of about half that amount for payment to farmers for works undertaken to farm buildings under the control of pollution programme and so on. The question must be asked as to why, in this age of technology, farmers cannot be paid on time for the work they do. I am getting a little tired of hearing about all the planning that goes on in the Department — I have also seen it for myself in my day.
